urn:contentItem:5RX2-9TW1-F0J6-J503-00000-00North rain to beat back late heatwave2018-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:29ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5North rain to beat back late heatwaveBenjamin.Doherty

The burst of late-season heat that seared south-eastern Australia over the weekend will give way to days of heavy showers for Sydney with bigger falls forecast for coastal regions to the north.

The falls, though, will likely be minimal over bushfire-hit parts of the NSW south coast where a forest fire danger index reached a record high for March, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

Sydney on Monday fell shy of hitting three consecutive March days of 30 degrees - which would have been the first such trio in the month since 1902 - with a top of 28.4 degrees.

A wind shift from the north-west that had brought warm air from central Australia to an easterly flow put a cap of temperatures.

"At this stage, it looks like [the trough] will have the biggest impact on the central coast and possibly even further north," said Rose Barr, at the bureau. "It is dependent on where this coastal feature develops."

Newcastle may be among the wettest locations, with 10-20 millimetres forecast for Tuesday and 90-120 millimetres on Wednesday. Thursday may also be wet, with 20-40 millimetres more possible. The heavier falls are likely to come from thunderstorms developing within the system, Ms Barr said. Tathra, where 69 homes were destroyed and 39 damaged in Sunday's fires, won't get much rain in the system, with Thursday's 2-8 millimetres the most for any of the coming days. The system is not likely to take on the form of an east coast low, Ms Barr said, noting the absence of upper-level conditions conducive to the more extreme rains and wind.

The heatwave included a range of record maximum March temperatures for towns on the NSW south coast, included 38.9 degrees at Moruya Airport and 38.1 degrees at Merimbula, the Bureau of Meteorology said. According to Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, the forest fire danger index "was the highest on record for March for most areas of the NSW South Coast from Nowra southwards, as well as far east Gippsland and parts of the Monaro" such as Bombala. On Saturday, every eastern capital - Adelaide, Hobart, Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, and Canberra - topped 30 degrees. That was the first time in March in 53 years and the latest in the season since records started including Canberra 80 years ago, Brett Dutschke, senior meteorologist at Weatherzone, said.

urn:contentItem:5XDB-9041-JD34-V1MN-00000-00Man charged with supply after drugs, goods seized in car stop2019-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisMan charged with supply after drugs, goods seized in car stopNewsroom

A man has been charged with drug supply after police allege they found methylamphetamine and cannabis in a shoe, during a car stop.

Officers conducted a vehicle stop on the Castlereagh Highway, about 10km south of Walgett, at 6.45pm on October 29.

Police questioned the occupants of the Holden Commodore stationwagon, during which the 31-year-old male passenger allegedly produced a backpack from the passenger footwell.

Inside, it allegedly contained cannabis leaf and other drug paraphernalia.

READ ALSO:

38 troops plus an air tanker: Extra firepower for wild forest fire Twins behind bars, charged in connection to backyard meth labs Night food markets cancelled in two towns after truck destroyed Officers conducted a further search of the car and the man and will allege they uncovered a quantity of methylamphetamine in the man's shoe.

The 31-year-old man was arrested and taken to Walgett police station where he was charged with two counts of supplying a prohibited drug.

He was granted conditional bail to appear before Walgett Local Court on November 12.

Police said the operation involved officers from the Walgett Criminal Investigation, the Target Action Group, Rural Crime Prevention Team and Crime Management Unit.

Central North Police Superintendent Andrew Hurst said the arrest stemmed from information provided by the community.

"The Central North Police District will continue to target the supply of prohibited drugs in our communities, and the people who are transporting drugs," he said.

"This arrest was the result of information from the community, and excellent teamwork from the various units and teams that work at the Walgett Police Station."

urn:contentItem:5VHF-KV71-F0J6-J28B-00000-00Land and fire management agenc...2019-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:29ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Land and fire management agenc...

Land and fire management agencies are calling on residents of Tarneit, Truganina, Melton and Wyndham Vale to develop plans to reduce the bushfire risk to households near Melbourne's western grasslands.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's forest and fire planning regional manager, Damien Taylor, said the planning process aimed to address fire risks on public and private land.

He said organisations involved in the planning included the CFA, Emergency Management Victoria and councils.

"We've had a lot of feedback from communities in Melbourne's eastern, more forested region, but we've had a less enthusiastic response from ... Melbourne's west," Mr Taylor said.

"We now need community input into bushfire management strategies to help us strike the right balance."

He said the organisations involved in the planning would also use technology, developed in partnership with the University of Melbourne, to identify areas around Melbourne's western grasslands where grassfires could pose the greatest risk to human lives and property.

"Previously, this planning process focused on bushfire risk across public land," Mr Taylor said.

"This time, we've broadened our focus to help determine where to target fuel management on public and private land."

Details: www.engage.vic.gov.au/bushfire-planning

urn:contentItem:5RWF-R2R1-F0J6-J55V-00000-00Anger as man's hand-dug mineshaft filled in near Dunolly2018-03-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEAnger as man's hand-dug mineshaft filled in near DunollyAdam Holmes

FOR more than two years, Robert Brown has used hand tools to dig a mine shaft in public bushland at the end of a dead end track north of Dunolly.

The 61-year-old prospector dug his mine 20 feet below the surface, and constructed an underground drive 30 feet across, where he was looking for gold to supplement his disability support pension.

His mine had bunting, pickets and protective mesh, similar to safety measures at other protected mine shafts in the area. He was at the site several times a week, except in winter.

The lack of a big haul of gold did not bother him - it was more of a hobby.

So when he arrived at the site on Sunday, February 25, to find it completely filled in by Forest Fire Management Victoria, he was furious.

"Unless somebody physically climbed down there and checked, they would have had no idea if anyone was working down there," Mr Brown said.

"They've destroyed two to three years of hard work, my hobby.

"If they filled it in and you were down there, you'd be dead."

Mr Brown claims he was operating under the miners right, which he believes allows for excavation using hand tools.

His tools are now buried under tonnes of dirt at the bottom of the mine.

The Prospectors and Miners Association of Victoria has supported Mr Brown in his attempt to get an explanation from the department and compensation for the loss of tools, labour and the hardship he suffered after seeing his work destroyed.

A number of meetings were held in relation to the matter and several hundred dollars in compensation was offered to replace the lost tools.

Mr Brown said the loss of tools was a minor matter, and he was more concerned with the loss of his years' of work.

Forest Fire Management Victoria claims it attempted to contact Mr Brown "more than a dozen times" over two years without success, and it was aware of the mineshaft since 2015.

District manager Paul Bates said the mine was filled in preparation for a controlled burn in the area.

"The mine shaft is located within a planned burn area scheduled to be carried out this autumn and a decision was made to fill the open shaft for the safety of firefighters," he said.

urn:contentItem:5VXB-8NJ1-F0J6-J09H-00000-00Trashed campsite cleaned up by crews2019-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisTrashed campsite cleaned up by crewsMonique Patterson

FURNITURE, white goods and household rubbish left by a group of people who were illegally camping in the Cobboboonee Forest has been removed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) forest management and roading officer Wes Burns said contractors removed almost 140 cubic metres of rubbish from the site over a number of days. "Rubbish removed included furniture, white goods, household rubbish and camping gear," Mr Burns said.

"FFMVic officers inspected the site to identify concealed traps and hazards to ensure these were also removed during the clean up."

Mr Burns said crews would start rehabilitation works to restore the site shortly.

He said illegally dumped rubbish affected the environment and presented safety issues.

"While this situation relates to a group illegally occupying the forest, rubbish being dumped on public land is not a new issue in the district," Mr Burns said.

"Our crews spend hundreds of hours every year cleaning up litter that has been irresponsibly dumped, instead of being disposed of correctly."

Mr Burns said the authority would rather spend time and money on upgrades for forests and parks.

"Help us ensure these spaces are respected and used responsibly and report any suspicious behaviour or littering directly to EPA Victoria on 1300 372 842," he said.

Infringements for litter related offences range from $322 to $1934.

urn:contentItem:5VXS-4N11-JD34-V4WT-00000-00Torched stolen car ignites grass fire at Invermay2019-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisTorched stolen car ignites grass fire at InvermayMichelle Smith

A torched stolen car ignited a grass fire which burned about five acres of land at Invermay overnight.

Fire crews were called to the corner of Slatey Creek Road and Tallowwwood Rise about 4.45am to find the stolen sedan destroyed and the surrounding grass and scrub alight.

First crews on the scene called for 10 tankers to help fight the blaze, which at one stage was burning toward a property at the northern end of Slatey Creek Road.

CFA rostered duty officer Ben Townsend said it was "very frustrating" being called to yet another burning car.

It continues the spate of more than 30 car blazes which have happened this year.

Ballarat City firefighters attended with their pumper and another six tankers from CFA stations in the surrounding area bought the blaze under control with Forest Fire Management Victoria also attending to deal with dangerous trees left weakened by the fire.

RELATED STORY: Soldiers Hill car fires, why arsonists burn

Police confirmed the sedan had been stolen.

Fire crews were still on the scene at 10.15am, blacking out areas to ensure they do not reignite.

urn:contentItem:5X12-5BK1-F0J6-J3DX-00000-00Bendigo men fined for illegally cutting firewood in state forest2019-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisBendigo men fined for illegally cutting firewood in state forest

TWO Bendigo men have been fined $661 each for illegally cutting wood outside of the designated firewood collection season in Gunbower State Forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria officers were patroling the forest last week when they allege they came across the pair, senior forest and fire operations officer Tim Wishart said.

The men were both given $661 on-the-spot fines and the wood was seized, he said.

"The firewood is being held as evidence in the event of further legal proceedings.

"By waiting a few more days until the spring firewood collection season opened ... they would have avoided a fine."

The designated firewood season started last Sunday and will close on 30 November.

It is illegal to cut or take away trees from the forest, under the Forest Act 1958.

The offence carries either an on-the-spot fine of $661 or a maximum penalty of one-year's imprisonment, a fine of up to $8261 or both, if the matter proceeds to court.

For more information on domestic firewood collection on public land, visit www.delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood

Mr Wishart encouraged anyone who sees something suspicious in forests and parks to report it on 136 186, to police, Parks Victoria or the Department of Environment Land, Water and Planning.

Calls can be made anonymously.

urn:contentItem:5X12-5BK1-F0J6-J39R-00000-00Bendigo men fined for illegally cutting firewood in state forest2019-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisSATURDAYBendigo men fined for illegally cutting firewood in state forest

TWO Bendigo men have been fined $661 each for illegally cutting wood outside of the designated firewood collection season in Gunbower State Forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria officers were patroling the forest last week when they allege they came across the pair, senior forest and fire operations officer Tim Wishart said.

The men were both given $661 on-the-spot fines and the wood was seized, he said.

"The firewood is being held as evidence in the event of further legal proceedings.

"By waiting a few more days until the spring firewood collection season opened ... they would have avoided a fine."

The designated firewood season started last Sunday and will close on 30 November.

It is illegal to cut or take away trees from the forest, under the Forest Act 1958.

The offence carries either an on-the-spot fine of $661 or a maximum penalty of one-year's imprisonment, a fine of up to $8261 or both, if the matter proceeds to court.

For more information on domestic firewood collection on public land, visit www.delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood

Mr Wishart encouraged anyone who sees something suspicious in forests and parks to report it on 136 186, to police, Parks Victoria or the Department of Environment Land, Water and Planning.

Calls can be made anonymously.

urn:contentItem:5P8F-YKX1-F0J6-J1V3-00000-00Planned burn off a great success2017-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Planned burn off a great successLachlan Williams

Crews from Forest Fire Management and the Pomonal CFA collaborated on Monday and Tuesday in an effort to reduce the amount of fire hazards in the area in the lead up to the fire season.

Crews engaged in candling along Lynches track and on private property at Pomonal that backs on to the Grampians National Park.

The burn had been planned from as far back as three years ago for the 2000 hectare space.

Forest Fire Management Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said the burn off was a success.

"It was a pretty good result with great conditions for what we were doing," he said.

"We finished up most off the burning on Monday, so Tuesday was mainly cleaning up and making sure everything was safe.

"The rain on Tuesday made life a bit easier."

Mr Rudolph said there were two clear objectives which were both achieved.

"We were candling to burn the bark off trees and piled up pieces of timber," he said.

"Bark is a big fuel in bushfires, causing embers and little spot fires. It is really important to reduce the bark hazard early."

With the success achieved from this burn off, Mr Rudolph said crews might not have to return to the area until next year.

"We will be planing to go back and treat some more areas near there next year," he said.

Mr Rudolph said the burn offs were also a great opportunity to work with local fire authorities.

"It is all apart of the Safer Together program, where the CFA, local government and communities work together" he said.

"The involvement from the Pomonal fire brigade and the interest from local community has been great. It has been a strong collaborative effort."

While the burn offs will significantly help in the event of a bush fire, Mr Rudolph said the community should still be aware of the threat of fire.

"It will help if a fire comes through, but the key message is that this won't stop a fire at Pomonal," he said.

"People need to make sure their bush fire plans are ready to prepare best for fire season."

urn:contentItem:5X8W-HGW1-F0J6-J155-00000-00Towns to evacuate for fire exercise2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Towns to evacuate for fire exerciseZach Hope

Three regional communities east of Melbourne will be evacuated next week in one of the state's biggest bushfire drills.

Close to 400 residents of the Yarra Ranges towns of Powellton, Three Bridges and Gilderoy will have the option to leave or stay on October 26, in a test of preparedness for what is expected to be a busy summer fire season.

Police, the Country Fire Authority, Yarra Ranges Council and Forest Fire Management Victoria will be involved in the exercise, before a community meeting in Powellton to discuss what worked and what could be improved.

While the exercise will run sometime between 2pm and 6pm on the Saturday, authorities do not want to be too specific about the action to make it as authentic as possible.

The communities will not shut down, meaning residents have the option to participate or carry on with business.

Victoria Police Assistant Commissioner Michael Grainger said the area around Powellton was chosen because of its recent history of severe bushfires, the community's willingness to engage and that it has one road in and out.

"Most have evacuation plans they've developed themselves already. What we're keen to do is test our processes, test our engagement with other agencies and with the community, and try to learn lessons from that process as we head into what we expect will be a really hot, dry summer period," Mr Grainger said.

The drill follows warnings that parts of Victoria face their worst bushfire threat since the Black Saturday bushfires of 2009.

A report from the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Research Centre, released last month, said East and West Gippsland and the Great Dividing Range faced the biggest threats after three years of below-average rainfall.

urn:contentItem:53KF-04C1-F09W-853J-00000-00Forest fire2011-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMCulturePg. 11Forest fireDANCEElissa Blake

Trees will need to audition for a role in this work for children, writes ELISSA BLAKE. You could be forgiven for assuming most dance works are fairly light on sets and props. After all, it's all about the body, isn't it? A shiny floor, a few lights, some clingy costumes ... what more do you need?

If you are British theatre company Fevered Sleep, the answer is: a lot. A stand of mature smooth-barked trees, for starters. The company's artistic director, David Harradine, makes the set for their production The Forest sound like something that could be installed at an art gallery. "The stage is a very long rectangle of metallic gold, very beautiful and reflective," he says. "It's like a catwalk. From that we have 11 real trees growing up out of the floor, and on top of the trees are sheets of mirror. The trees are reflected in the mirror and appear to go on and on and on, much taller than they are. And all around that are hundreds of tiny little light bulbs - like stars in the sky or leaves on the trees." Due to Australia's quarantine regulations on the importation of forest products, Fevered Sleep will arrive a week ahead of its shows to source suitable trees here. It won't be a matter of going bush with a chainsaw, however. The Sydney Opera House will guide the company to plantations that specialise in trees for film and television productions. "We'll be auditioning the trees very carefully," Harradine jokes. He describes The Forest as a work for young audiences exploring the landscape through movement, music, light and sound: the forest as a place to play in, to explore, to be afraid in and become lost in. "Forests are significant for children because of the forests in fairytales and mythology, the stories they've heard," Harradine says. "But as a theatre company based in central London, we find many children in our audiences have never experienced a forest for themselves, so we can play around with the idea of what a forest might be like." Harradine says that in the work created by Fevered Sleep for young audiences, he is always mindful that children live complex emotional lives. "I think children are very sophisticated, so we don't shy away from exploring the darker sides of the forest," he says. "But the show is grounded in playfulness and delight - the delight that comes from being in a place like this. Occasionally, the performers encounter the darker side but the sun always comes up. It always comes back to a place of play. It's a light show with dark edges." Since Fevered Sleep formed in 1996, the company has produced a wide range of movement-driven theatre. The Forest has been praised widely for its integration of technical and human elements. "All our shows are different," Harradine says. "We don't get hung up on the discipline or form of it. Some shows are theatre and some are dance and some we don't really know what we've made. It's just 'something'. We work across all performance forms and beyond performance as well, into visual art and installation projects as well." Fevered Sleep's success has led many to think of the company as a children's theatre specialist - The Forest is part of the Sydney Opera House's Spring Dance festival and the Kids at the House series - but Harradine says they didn't start with a particular audience in mind. "We've been around for 15 years and for the first eight of those, we didn't make anything for children," he says. "Because of that, the way we approach work for children is the same process as for adults. We craft the work just as carefully, the structure is just as sophisticated and the dramaturgy is every bit as complex as anything we do for an adults audience." The main difference Harradine perceives is in the work's reception. Unlike adults, children quickly enter the world of the work. "They're drawn in and respond vocally and those responses become as much a part of the event as the performance itself," he says. The Forest plays at the Sydney Opera House on September 3 and 4.

PHOTO: Growth industry ... Fevered Sleep approaches work for children as it does work for adults.

urn:contentItem:5XT6-T8D1-F0J6-J3F4-00000-00Accused firebug arrested2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Accused firebug arrestedKyra Gillespie, Jessica Howard

An alleged firebug will face court next year after his vehicle was seen leaving the scene of a grass fire in the south-west.

A 21-year-old man from the Casterton area was arrested on Saturday morning after two grass fires were allegedly lit near Dunan and Ridge Roads, Henty.

He has been charged with two counts of arson and was bailed to appear in court next year. Police would not confirm any other details about the fires.

Meanwhile, almost every south-west fire brigade was deployed over the weekend as bushfires burnt across the region. Heywood incident controller Mark Mellington said he believed more than 1000 hectares of land had been torched by fire.

He said Friday had "fairly nasty weather conditions followed by a significant lightening event in the evening".

"We had a number of fires start on Friday night as a result of that lightening," he said.

"Majority of the fires occurred throughout the south-western part of Victoria, including west of Casterton, around the Dartmoor and Digby areas, and further west in the Cobboboonee Forest."

Mr Mellington said "every available resource had been called for".

"We've used a range of aircraft for fire bombing as well as aerial observation to try and help us to understand the extent of the fires," he said.

"We've also had a significant number of heavy machinery to help with the construction of fire lines, as well as a number of trucks and water carrying freights from both CFA and Forest Fire Management."

No lives or properties have been reported lost.

Mr Mellington said it had been a long weekend for firefighters.

"A lot of our firefighters have already had several rotations through to either Gippsland or interstate," he said. "In terms of how people are travelling, we're at the stage that we would ordinarily be at much later in the season."

urn:contentItem:5PWY-GRT1-JD34-V2SW-00000-00Emergency services aim for increased communication2017-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSEmergency services aim for increased communicationCarly Werner

WIMMERA emergency services will increase communication with residents during the 2017-18 fire season.

Services staff and volunteers met in Horsham for a pre-summer season briefing.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said among the topics discussed at last month's forum was the services' use of text messages to alert residents to fire conditions.

"This year we will probably be using the SMS system more to give people more information as it happens," he said. "It won't be just necessarily be about warnings. In the past we've used it for things like evacuation notifications and emergency warnings - it has been more about the impacts.

"We want to use it more often to help share information with people. It is an easy way to get information out with a platform that most people now use and are familiar with."

Mr Rudolph said the event at Grains Innovation Park involved about 60 people from the Country Fire Authority, Victoria Police, the State Emergency Service, Parks Victoria, the Department of Health and Human Services, Emergency Management Victoria, and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"We also discussed updating some of the things around our standard operation produces and how we work together across agencies," he said.

"We covered the new technology and the systems we have available, including improvements to the computer platform we use - the Emergency Management Common Operation Picture or EM-COP - that allows us to share information between agencies.

"It is really quite a useful thing. Another big focus at the briefing was intelligence sharing to better capture the impact of fires on communities as they happen.

"We also had a briefing on how we manage the warnings and the public information side of things."

Mr Rudolph said air quality monitoring improvements were also discussed.

"The State Emergency Service has the ability to set up air quality monitoring stations to help us work out the impacts fires might have on communities from a smoke point of view," he said.

Mr Rudolph said the annual briefing was a chance for agencies to understand key changes that would affect their work in the season ahead.

"It's a fantastic opportunity for all emergency management organisations to get together, and it highlights how connected we all are these days," he said.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R1X1-00000-00BID TO MAKE RAIN FALL ON MONGOLIAN FOREST FIRE1987-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:29ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 13BID TO MAKE RAIN FALL ON MONGOLIAN FOREST FIRESource: Reuter

BEIJING, Sunday: As China's worst forest fire in memory spreads towards Inner Mongolia, Beijing is sending artillery to fire rain-making shells, the official media said last night.

State radio said the western sector of the fire, moving slowly south, was within 10 kilometres of vast virgin forests in Inner Mongolia, which it said were threatened from two directions.

The Peking Evening News said the blaze had broken through a firebreak 120 kilometres long, and was spreading south.

In the past two weeks, the fire has killed more than 200 people, made 50,000 homeless and devastated 600,000 hectares in the nearby Heilongjiang province.

The main news broadcast from State television said firefighters had been sent to the west from the eastern sector, where the fire was largely under control.

Men and material were pouring into the disaster area, including nearly 300 men armed with 18 pieces of artillery with 10,000 shells which could be fired at clouds to create artificial rain.

Specialist communications and medical teams and 140,000 shells containing rain-making chemicals were also being despatched.

The television showed Chinese Air Force aircraft flying in tents, medicines, food and equipment donated by Japanese Red Cross.

Floods have covered vast areas of southern China. In Hong Kong, the pro-Peking newspaper Ta Kung Pao reported that storms in the southern province of Guangdong had killed 68 people and flooded nearly 200,000 hectares of farmland.

A flood warning in Beijing pointed to the first recurrence in 24 years of sunspot activity, combined with the climatic phenomenon known as El Nino, meant danger.

El Nino, caused by temperature variations in the waters off the coast of South America, disrupts normal weather patterns on both sides of the Pacific.

The pro-Peking Wen Wei Po newspaper in Hong Kong said that 145,000 people died when El Nino affected China badly in 1931, and the death toll in 1954 was 30,000.

The New China News Agency reported yesterday that torrential rain had killed six people and seriously injured six others in Shenzhen, next to Hong Kong, on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5X65-96K1-JD34-V109-00000-00Fuel reduction burn planned north of Heathcote2019-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burn planned north of Heathcote

SMOKE might be visible from Heathcote, Costerfield, Mount Camel and Redcastle during a planned burn next week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA plan to carry out a 172-hectare burn in the Heathcote-Graytown National Park.

The burn should be completed between 10am on Monday and 8pm on Wednesday.

Smoke might be visible for several days afterwards.

The fire will take place along Dargile Track, six kilometres north of Heathcote.

Fire authorities have provided the following advice:

What to do about: SMOKE If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024 Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering. ROADS Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn For travel times and roadworks check traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au ACCESS TO FOREST/PARK RECREATION SITES Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt. Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted. For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit parkweb.vic.gov.au Have you signed up to the Bendigo Advertiser's daily newsletter and breaking news emails? You can register below and make sure you are up to date with everything that's happening in central Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5M91-CNR1-JD34-V04W-00000-00Planned burns to go ahead, weather permitting2016-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisPlanned burns to go ahead, weather permitting

Three planned burns are expected to go ahead today as the Environment Department takes advantage of the last opportunity to burn off before summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields district manager Paul Bates said the department planned to conduct burns in Kangaroo Flat, Huntly and Chinamans Hill "depending on the weather", while a fourth burn in Golden Square was called off.

"The first two fuel reduction burns will be a 56-hectare burn at Irwin Lane in Kangaroo Flat and a two-hectare burn at Chinamans Hill, two kilometres north west of Rushworth," he said.

"Also on today, a planned burn around three hectares in size will be conducted at Viola Road in Huntly."

Mr Bates said, again weather permitting, the cancelled 23-hectare Golden Square burn would go ahead at Specimen Hill Channel on Saturday.

"The aim of conducting the burns is to reduce the overall fuel hazard within the burn area and in turn, provide added protection from bushfire to neighbouring communities," he said.

"The landscape is drying out as we move into summer and we have a brief period in which to reduce the fuel hazard in these areas through planned burning.

"To effectively reduce fuel, we need to carry out burns in the bush and in areas close to communities."

Mr Bates said the burns close to residential areas were "carried out by experienced Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters, under carefully managed conditions", and advised residents not to panic if they saw smoke.

"We ask that if people see smoke and are concerned, they ring the VicEmergency Hotline, not triple zero," he said.

"It is important triple zero is only used in case of emergency if you see flames."

urn:contentItem:5W2C-R5C1-F0J6-J38R-00000-00Emergency crews control bushfire at Edenhope2019-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisEmergency crews control bushfire at EdenhopeJade Bate

UPDATE 5PM:

Six fire trucks have brought a grass fire burning southeast of Edenhope under control, with the aid of rain.

A Country Fire Authority spokesman said firefighters contained the blaze just after 4pm. VicEmergency said the blaze burnt one hectare of grassland near Powers Creek Road.

The spokesman said there was never any threat to life or property.

It followed two fire crews heading to a farm on Hicks Road at Ozenkadnook at 2.30 on Tuesday afternoon, where they needed two hours to fully extinguish another grass fire.

Smoke was also visible in Nhill and Apsley on Tuesday, as Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA conducted planned burns near each town.

PREVIOUSLY:

EMERGENCY crews are responding to a bushfire at Powers Creek Road, Edenhope, that is not yet under control.

The grassfire is travelling in a north-westerly direction and is south of the Edenhope township.

The Country Fire Authority has advised residents that there is currently no threat to human life, but that they should stay informed and monitor conditions.

Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

will fail: Network </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">OTWAY Ranges Environment Network has condemned the native forest woodchip industry for using the bushfire issue to scare the community  out of supporting Otways national parks.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Spokesman Simon Birrell said the network was concerned that the fire situation in the Otways was being wrongly compared with the bushfires in Canberra and northeast Victoria earlier this year.</p><p>But he said the network was confident that attempts to use the bushfire issue to scare the community would fail.</p><p>"The forests of the northeast and Canberra are dryer forests in low rainfall areas; the Otways has wet forests with the highest rainfall in Victoria, which makes the tall mountain forests of the Otways naturally fire resistant," Mr Birrell said.</p><p>"Research shows that before European settlement, wet forests had a fire frequency of once every 300 to 500 years.</p><p>"Where cool temperate rainforest grows in the Otways, it is so wet that it has not burnt for thousands or millions of years.</p><p>"Ironically, the dry foothill forests and heathlands in the Otways which are fire prone are already in state parks, such as the Carlisle State Park and Angahook Lorne State Park.</p><p>Mr Birrell claimed that logging practices were in fact increasing the risk of bushfires in the Otways, arguing that scientific research had shown that clearfell logging was making the wet forests of the Otways drier and more fire prone.</p><p>"Logging destroys all the tree ferns and understorey species that help create a cool micro-climate that helps retain moisture and lower fire risk," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4M8C-5PW0-TX53-21VV-00000-00How the malignancy made its mark like a rampaging forest fire2006-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 3How the malignancy made its mark like a rampaging forest fire

March 2003: First public reports of a mysterious cancer-like disease killing Tasmanian devils.

January 2005: Researchers say the disease has killed 40,000 to 80,000 devils in 10 years.

February 2005: Plans to build a ''Noah's Ark'' population on Maria Island.

June 2005: Four devils in captivity at Taroona vanish, believed dead.

July 2005: Tasmanian researchers tell an international conference in Cairns the devil disease is highly malignant and may transplant mechanically from one devil to another.

July 2005: Researchers investigate ''rotten apple'' theory suggesting one devil in North-East developed a rare cancer, perhaps due to chemical pollution, which is spreading across the state.

August 2005: Park operators say they are being kept in the dark about the disease.

October 2005: A former ranger says hundreds of Tasmanian devils were poisoned at the same time and place.

October 2005: Premier Paul Lennon announces the state will send a healthy pair of Tasmanian devils to Denmark to celebrate the birth of the Danish prince.

April 2006: Shipment of devils from Trowunna Wildlife Park leaves for Denmark.

April 2006: Formal listing of the Tasmanian devil as vulnerable.

July 2006: Escape of a diseased devil from secure enclosure at research facility in Launceston.

October 2006: Disease confirmed in two devils from Trowunna Wildlife Park.

urn:contentItem:5VGC-S3G1-F0J6-J1WV-00000-00Candelo RFS members go to help out in 21,000ha Victorian bushfire2019-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisCandelo RFS members go to help out in 21,000ha Victorian bushfireAlbert McKnight

Two of the Candelo Rural Fire Service's youngest members headed to Victoria on Wednesday to help their southern neighbours.

It is the second major deployment for Jack Matthews, 21, and Matt Jennings, 20, who have been part of the Candelo team since they were in their early teens and have fought in last year's Tathra and Yankees Gap bushfires.

They plan on assisting the Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria outside Buchan, north of Orbost, controlling and putting out hotspots around backburning that is taking place to stop a bushfire that has reached 21,000ha and has been going for over 40 days.

Mr Matthews said the two were hoping to build up enough experience to get into the Remote Area Firefighting Team back home.

"It's also about coming down and helping out. These guys come up and help us so it's about us helping them too," he said.

Mr Jennings, a fifth generation firefighter, said firefighting ran in his blood.

Candelo fire brigade captain Harmen Kampman it would be a good experience for the two to have.

"They're pretty experienced boys now, they have been with the brigade since they were both about 12," he said.

"They've done well for themselves and are pretty confident too."

urn:contentItem:5R6F-JT81-JD3N-551B-00000-00THE BIG DRY2017-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 28THE BIG DRYFireys on high alert as state ready to burn IAN ROYALL

DRY areas of central Victoria and Gippsland are the most vulnerable to bushfire this summer as fire crews have gone on high alert for an early start to the fire season.

Dry vegetation and the early arrival of the fire-prone period has limited burning-off and fuel loads have increased during spring, sparking fears of an above-normal fire danger season.

Satellite imagery has revealed how the state has dried out in the past three months, despite recent bursts of rain in early December.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman said an above-normal fire season was expected, with a potentially earlier start in some areas.

"The higher risk areas include all metropolitan areas - Melbourne to Geelong, the area from Ballarat and Bendigo, across to Echuca, Shepparton, Wodonga, and the Latrobe Valley and East Gippsland areas," the spokesman said.

CFA chief officer Steve Warrington said the dry conditions in far East Gippsland meant that fire restrictions had been put in place earlier than ever before.

"It is just so dry down there and they missed the rain," Mr Warrington said. "So on the back of that we brought forward all our preparedness and so did Parks Vic and DELWP as well," he said.

"That whole eastern side of the state is problematic." New equipment is being brought in this year to lead the battle against fire danger.

Forest Fire Management crews this summer have 21 firefighting Unimogs - and all-terrain Mercedes-Benz - ready for action.

The off-road Unimogs can carry 4000 litres of water, have falling objection protection on the roof and has a cabin deluge system for crew protection.

Victoria will also have a core fleet of 49 aircraft - a combination of water bombing, air supervision and reconnaissance aircraft.

An extra water bomber will be based at Bacchus Marsh this year, and will help serve the north and west outer metropolitan areas.

Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said the community would be better protected.

"Our firefighters always do a fantastic job on the ground, and the aircraft we are launching will support that," Mr Lapsley said.

Victoria also has two large air tankers and two orange air-cranes which follow first-response aircraft. "Last week's rain means that in some areas there would be new grass shoots, which means when that dries out, there will be more fuel to burn," Mr Lapsley said.

urn:contentItem:5XH3-X8S1-JD34-V1B4-00000-00Grampians group shares the load2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:29ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Grampians group shares the loadJade Bate and Alexander Darling

WIMMERA and Grampians volunteers are among 1200 people fighting bushfires in New South Wales.

Country Fire Authority volunteers from districts 15 and 16 formed part of a strike team that fought a fire in Wollemi National Park, northwest of Sydney, on Tuesday.

The Stawell Fire Brigade said three members would return on Friday, while another would travel to Coffs Harbour on the NSW north coast to help in operations until Sunday.

Another 15 Ararat and Stawell volunteers traveled to NSW on Wednesday morning.

District 16 commander Neville Collins said volunteers regularly "inundated" the district with requests to participate when large fires flared up interstate.

"The volunteers will work three days of 12-hour shifts and probably travel home Friday," he said.

On Wednesday, Forest Fire Management Victoria deployed four firefighters from the Wimmera district and ten from the Grampians district as part of a 28-member strike team.

Acting deputy chief fire officer Sharon Unthank said the task force would be deployed for seven days.

"(It will) increase numbers of firefighters on the ground to share the workload, combat fatigue and keep the community safe," she said.

A group of 11 Country Fire Authority District 17 volunteers from the Horsham district travelled to NSW on Thursday to join strike teams on the ground.

District 17 Horsham group officer Roger Perris said the group would help undertake back-burning and would maintain burns.

Red Cross Emergency Services Victorian manager Kate Siebert said Wimmera volunteers hadn't been requested to support New South Wales and Queensland.

"However, the teams could and certainly would if they were needed," she said.

At midday on Thursday, there were 59 fires burning around NSW, with 30 uncontained and six at 'watch and act' level. A fourth person was confirmed dead on Thursday.

urn:contentItem:5XH3-X8S1-JD34-V0Y3-00000-00Volunteers deployed2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Volunteers deployedAlexander Darling

WIMMERA and Grampians volunteers have helped to fight out of control bushfires in New South Wales across the week.

Country Fire Authority volunteers from districts 15 and 16 formed part of a strike team that fought a fire in Wollemi National Park, northwest of Sydney, on Tuesday.

The Stawell Fire Brigade said three members would return on Friday, while another would travel to Coffs Harbour, on the NSW mid north coast to help in operations until Sunday.

Another 15 Ararat and Stawell volunteers traveled to NSW on Wednesday morning.

District 16 commander Neville Collins said volunteers regularly "inundated" the district with requests to participate when large fires flared up interstate.

"The volunteers will work three days of 12-hour shifts and probably travel home Friday," he said.

On Wednesday, Forest Fire Management Victoria deployed four firefighters from the Wimmera district and ten from the Grampians district as part of a 28-member strike team with the Midlands district and Loddon-Mallee region firefighters.

Acting deputy chief fire officer Sharon Unthank said the task force would be deployed for seven days.

"(It will) increase numbers of firefighters on the ground to share the workload, combat fatigue and keep the community safe," she said.

The CFA's operations manager of learning development, Christian Thorley, said 11 volunteers from District 17 left Horsham on Thursday.

"At this stage they are flying into the Richmond airforce base camp near Sydney and will be deployed on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, to return on Monday," he said.

District 17 operations officer Alfred Mason said the CFA paid volunteers' travel, accommodation and food costs while they were deployed.

At 10am on Thursday, the NSW Rural Fire Service said there were 56 bush and grass fires burning across the state, with 24 still to be contained.

The service said there were still more than 800 firefighters in the field working on containing these fires.

urn:contentItem:5V9G-DMV1-F0J6-J4MR-00000-00Emergency services control small bushfire burning at Knowsley2019-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisEmergency services control small bushfire burning at Knowsley

3pm

IT IS too early to determine what caused a small fire at Knowsley on Tuesday.

A Country Fire Authority spokeswoman said the fire spread to about half an acre before being controlled at 2.33pm.

The fire is now listed as controlled.

The spokeswoman said five trucks remained at the scene for black-out efforts.

2.45pm

Police are directing traffic at McIvor Highway at Knowsley after a small scrub fire.

Traffic is reduced to one lane in the area.

Two Forest Fire Management vehicles are at the scene, with crews raking the ground and helping with blacking out.

Two Country Fire Authority trucks also remain at the site.

2.25pm

A fire at Knowsley is now under control. Up to six trucks attended the blaze.

2.15pm

FIREFIGHTERS are on their way to a small scrub fire at Knowsley.

Emergency services received a call for the fire about 2.05pm on Tuesday.

Three trucks are headed to the scene to monitor the blaze.

A Country Fire Authority spokeswoman said at this stage the fire was small but firefighters would monitor it.

urn:contentItem:5V80-MF61-F0J6-J3C0-00000-00UPDATE: Most North East fires contained2019-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisUPDATE: Most North East fires containedBlair Thomson

10.45PM TUESDAY:

Most of the fires started by lightning across the North East were contained or under control by late on Tuesday night.

Forest Fire Management Victoria incident controller Scott Thomson said containment lines had been constructed after fires started outside Wodonga and throughout the Upper Murray, near Tallangatta and Corryong.

Mr Thomson praised the work of CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria officials, with the fires to be monitored throughout the night and into Wednesday morning.

"FFMVic and CFA firefighters on the ground were supported by aircraft, heavy machinery, including dozers and a rappel crew from Ovens," Mr Thomson said.

"Containment lines have been constructed, however some of the fires are still burning within the containment lines.

"The fires will continue to be monitored into the night and ground and rappel crews will commence work first thing tomorrow morning.

"Aircraft will also undertake water bombing operations to help suppress the fires and residents in the area may see or smell smoke.

"While these fires weren't threatening communities, it's a timely reminder on how quickly a bushfire can start in extremely hot weather conditions.

"During the coming days temperatures will remain very high across much of northern Victoria, with strong north westerly and a gusty wind change on Friday, which will contribute to the increased fire danger."

"Because of the prolonged heat, the region is extremely dry and any fires which start will be difficult to contain and may spread quickly."

"We need people to be prepared for the potential impact of fires and have a clear plan for what they will do if fire threatens. This includes accessing information from the VicEmergency app, website or emergency broadcasters."

5.45PM TUESDAY:

A SHORT thunderstorm set off multiple grass and scrub fires in the North East on Tuesday.

Firefighters were dispatched to a large number of fires about 3.10pm, including one on Huon Hill at Wodonga.

Water bombing aircraft were deployed to the incidents and an advice warning was put out to residents near the area.

People were warned there were no threats to their homes, but were urged to monitor the situation.

Bandiana residents were closely watching the incident.

"They seemed to have it very well under control with the water bombing," Freda Hall said near the scene.

Fires were reported at Black Range Road and Plunketts Road at West Wodonga, Mt Granya, Tallangatta East, Annandale Road at Bullioh, and at Wises Creek Road at Talgarno.

Another was reported on the Murray River Road at Thologolong, and firefighters also responded further east at Guys Forest and Burrowye.

WHAT ELSE IS MAKING NEWS:

4PM TUESDAY:

FIREFIGHTERS are working to extinguish multiple fires started on the Border following lightning strikes.

Multiple units have been called to Huon Hill after a blaze started about 3.10pm on Tuesday.

The fire is not yet under control and thick smoke can be seen billowing from the scene.

The fire is travelling east towards Kenneth Watson Drive and Whytes Road, but there is no threat to properties at this stage.

Residents at Bandiana, Baranduda, Bonegilla and Killara are urged to monitor the conditions.

Fires have also been reported at Black Range Road and Plunketts Road at West Wodonga, Mt Granya, Tallangatta East, Annandale Road at Bullioh, at Wises Creek Road at Talgarno.

Another blaze has been reported at Murray River Road at Thologolong.

People can monitor the incidents at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/

Temperatures around Albury-Wodonga dropped by more than 10 degrees, from 40 to below 30, as stormy weather swept through the area.

Up to 10mm of rain fell in parts across the Border, while others received no rainfall as strong winds hit the region.

urn:contentItem:5VJV-NV81-JC0X-K1YP-00000-00VIC:Vic bushfire conditions tipped to ease2019-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Vic bushfire conditions tipped to easeMELBOURNE March 5

  Holiday-makers are warned to steer clear of camping grounds in Wilsons Promontory National Park ahead of the long weekend as fires burn across the state.


   The park will remain closed until further notice as Forest Fire Management Victoria works to suppress a fire in inaccessible terrain.
   The news comes as weather conditions later in the week are expected to both help and hinder fire-fighting efforts.
   Cooler temperatures are expected to bring welcome relief, but a severe thunderstorm warning could bring flash flooding and dry lightning.
   A severe thunderstorm warning was issued for East Gippsland and North East districts on Monday night, and is expected to provide some much-needed relief for firefighters battling the blaze in Dargo.
   But those battling the Bunyip fire may not see any relief until early on Wednesday morning, with the cool change predicted to arrive then.
   At least two homes, and nine structures in total, have been destroyed by the latest round of devastating bushfires, with the CFA saying they expect the official number to rise over the next few days.
   There are six Watch and Act warnings in place across the state covering more than 50 towns.
   Residents living in those areas were warned that leaving is the safest option.
   More than 2000 firefighters are battling blazes across the state alongside 71 aircraft and help from NSW.

urn:contentItem:4R8G-PWC0-TX4S-M192-00000-00Garrett facing his first forest fire2007-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisAPg. 1Garrett facing his first forest fireRosslyn BeebyScience and Environment Reporter

Federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett faces a tough early test of his new portfolio powers after a Federal Court decision yesterday to allow logging in the Wielangta forest on Tasmania's east coast.

Under federal law, Mr Garrett has the power to intervene to prevent logging of the old growth rainforest.

If he refuses to act, furious opposition is expected from the Greens and peak conservation groups, which would quickly embroil the newly elected Labor Government.

Greens preferences delivered about 21 seats for Labor during last Saturday's election. In Hobart yesterday, the appeal bench of the Federal Court unanimously over-ruled a previous decision by Justice Shane Marshall that logging in the 10,000ha old growth forest was illegal because of its impact on the habitat of endangered wildlife.

After a trial involving scientists and 33 days of hearings, Justice Marshall ruled last year that logging would destroy the habitat of Tasmania's wedge-tailed eagle, swift parrot and one of Australia's rarest insects, the Wielangta stag beetle.

The Federal Court win by Australian Greens leader Bob Brown was hailed by environment groups and scientists as a watershed decision upholding the protection of Australia's native forests.

But after yesterday's decision upholding an appeal by Forestry Tasmania, Senator Brown faces more than $25,000 in costs and the prospect of another costly battle if he has legal grounds to lodge an appeal with the High Court.

Senator Brown has written to Mr Garrett asking him to take "urgent action to protect Wielangta and other native forests in Australia."

The Federal Court appeal bench upheld the Justice Marshall's previous finding that logging had "a significant and unacceptable impact" on endangered species in the Wielangta forest, but ruled logging was exempt from federal environment protection laws.

Forestry Tasmania and the National Association of Forest Industries welcomed the decision as providing the forestry industry with certainty for future timber supplies.

"This has been an expensive, emotionally draining and time consuming exercise but it has been worth it. There is now no doubt that our forestry operations are legal," Forestry Tasmania's managing director Bob Gordon said.

The court found once a 20-year regional forestry agreement was signed by state and federal governments, the impact of it could continue if both signatories agreed to allow it.

"It's a case of the law intends to protect endangered wildlife but if Canberra and Hobart ignore logging which endangers their existence, they can," Senator Brown said.

urn:contentItem:5V4P-BB91-JC0X-K26K-00000-00VIC:Fresh warning for those near Vic bushfire2019-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Fresh warning for those near Vic bushfireMELBOURNE Jan 6

  A fresh watch-and-act warning has been issued for communities near a large bushfire in Victoria's east.


   Residents in Stradbroke, Stradbroke West, Willung, Willung South are being warned to stay close to buildings they can shelter in after the blaze at Rosedale flared on several fronts on Sunday afternoon.
   "Firefighters have been unable to stop the spread of the fire," the message says.
   The CFA says the fire is moving south in some parts and southeast elsewhere.
   Air tankers and additional firefighters are being deployed to the firefront.
   "Staying close to a building you can shelter in is the safest option as conditions can change suddenly," the CFA says.
   An emergency relief centre is open at Sale Baptist Church, Lot 2 Princes Highway, Sale.
   The fire, which had been moving northeast on Saturday, has burned more than 10,000 hectares including a significant amount of pine plantations.
   So far fencing has been the only private property to be destroyed, authorities say, but there are concerns for native animals in the area.
   At one stage on Friday, the blaze turned on about 40 firefighters in a predicted wind change and destroyed a fire truck, trailer and bulldozer belonging to Forest Fire Management.
   A review will be conducted into how the firefighters came to be in harm's way.

urn:contentItem:5RGK-H9V1-F0JP-W4BP-00000-00PLAY IT SAFE MATES2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4PLAY IT SAFE MATESERIN PEARSON

AUSSIES are being warned to play it safe this Australia Day long weekend with high temperatures and the risk of fire.

Forest Fire Management Victoria asked the public to stay vigilant and informed and said firefighters were on standby.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Acting Chief Fire Officer, Darrin McKenzie said with forests and parks especially dry, the forecast was of particular concern.

He said this summer firefighters had already attended 127 campfires that had been left unattended or not extinguished correctly.

"We're urging anyone going camping, especially on the long weekend, to stay informed about the weather and be observant of what is happening around you when you are in the bush," he said.

"People must be careful, especially when it comes to campfires as gusty winds will easily carry embers out of a campfire and into the bush.

"Check the weather conditions and if it is a Total Fire Ban (TFB) do not have a campfire." Those set to hit the beach to celebrate the nation's special day are urged to keep an eye on their mates around the water.

Don't let your mates drink and drown this Australia Day - that's the message from Life Saving Victoria with booze-related drownings accounting for 20 per cent of the state's toll each year.

Principal Research Associate Bernadette Matthews said the risk was heightened on Australia Day as many headed to the beach, pool, lakes or rivers to celebrate the public holiday and long weekend.

On average, nine drownings in Victoria each year are alcohol related and statistics show nine out of 10 alcohol related drownings involve males, most aged between 25 and 44.

Dr Matthews said typical activities prior to drowning include swimming and unintentional entry into water such as slips, trips and falls.

"In many cases, people who have been drinking make poor decisions about entering the water or they unintentionally slip or fall in," she said.

"Alcohol not only affects your judgment of situations, but also your ability to respond and react.

"Around the water, this means you are more likely to fall and less likely to be able to get yourself out of trouble." Dr Matthews said it's important to drink responsibly around water and swim with a friend where possible.

Unintentional water entry accounted for 40 per cent of fatal drownings in Victoria last year.

"Alcohol affects your swimming ability and judgment of dangerous situations," Dr Matthews said.

"It's important to look out for your mates around water, and always have a designated non-drinker who can look out for your safety and respond in case of an emergency," she said."Don't let your mates drink and drown."

urn:contentItem:5VGC-S3G1-F0J6-J1XY-00000-00Candelo RFS members go to help out in 21,000ha Victorian bushfire2019-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSCandelo RFS members go to help out in 21,000ha Victorian bushfireAlbert McKnight

Two of the Candelo Rural Fire Service's youngest members headed to Victoria on Wednesday to help their southern neighbours.

It is the second major deployment for Jack Matthews, 21, and Matt Jennings, 20, who have been part of the Candelo team since they were in their early teens and have fought in last year's Tathra and Yankees Gap bushfires.

They plan on assisting the Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria outside Buchan, north of Orbost, controlling and putting out hotspots around backburning that is taking place to stop a bushfire that has reached 21,000ha and has been going for over 40 days.

Mr Matthews said the two were hoping to build up enough experience to get into the Remote Area Firefighting Team back home.

"It's also about coming down and helping out. These guys come up and help us so it's about us helping them too," he said.

Mr Jennings, a fifth generation firefighter, said firefighting ran in his blood.

Candelo fire brigade captain Harmen Kampman it would be a good experience for the two to have.

"They're pretty experienced boys now, they have been with the brigade since they were both about 12," he said.

"They've done well for themselves and are pretty confident too."

urn:contentItem:5T1F-DWS1-F0J6-J4N0-00000-00Sunbury firefighters are neede...2018-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Sunbury firefighters are neede...

Sunbury firefighters are needed for the upcoming fire season.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has begun recruiting project firefighters across the state.

More than 120 positions will be offered in the Hume region.

Hume assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse said project firefighters play a vital role in keeping communities and the environment safe from bushfires.

"Across the state there are over 300 project firefighter summer positions available, as well as 18 designated positions for applicants who identify as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander," Mr Hayse said.

"These frontline forest firefighters are an important addition to our resources."

More than 1000 frontline forest firefighters will be supported by 2000 staff from across various government departments.

"Project firefighters respond to bushfires, support seasonal planned burning preparation and delivery, undertake roadside vegetation and fire trail maintenance," Mr Hayse said.

"Successful recruits will learn new skills and make a significant contribution to their local community."

These jobs will be based at Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning and Parks Victoria offices and depots in regional Victoria. Applications close on August 26.

Details: www.ffm.vic.gov.au

Esther Lauaki

urn:contentItem:5VCR-CDC1-DYG0-927R-00000-00NZ:Thousands flee raging New Zealand fires2019-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSNZ:Thousands flee raging New Zealand firesAUCKLAND Feb 9

  Some 3000 people have fled their homes in New Zealand as firefighters struggle to halt the country's largest forest fire in more than half a century.


   More than 150 firefighters, 23 helicopters and two planes were on Saturday battling the 2100-hectare blaze near the South Island town of Nelson for a fifth day, with a state of emergency still in place, Fire and Emergency New Zealand said.
   As the fire lurched towards the small town of Wakefield, 860 homes were evacuated by authorities, adding to about 400 people who earlier fled the Pigeon Valley, where the blaze started on Tuesday.
   New Zealand has seen some significant scrub and grassland fires, but the Nelson blaze is thought to be the biggest to tear through forest land since 1955.
   Though no serious injuries have been reported, one house burned down earlier in the week.
   While additional crews and increased humidity are likely to help the effort, fears wind could pick up over the weekend meant the situation was "in the hands of the gods", incident controller John Sutton told media.
   "Our most significant efforts are currently focused on a fire front near Wakefield which is moving slowly downslope," Fire and Emergency said.
   The fire is believed to have been started at a nearby farm.
   Fire crews have, meanwhile, contained several other blazes that broke out in the region during the week amid drought-like conditions.

urn:contentItem:5M44-1SP1-JD34-V43K-00000-00Fire plan puts the spotlight on burns2016-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisFire plan puts the spotlight on burns

PROPOSED changes to fire management could see the frequency of planned burns decrease in some central Victorian towns, but increase in others.

The potential amendments to fire management zone guidelines are based on a new risk modelling approach by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Under the proposal, areas of higher fire risk might be subjected to more planned burns, while the opposite would apply to lower risk areas.

Forest Fire Management's website provides results for specific areas that can give residents an indication as to whether their areas could receive either increased or decreased fire management.

The proposed changes come as the CFA has warned Victoria to prepare for a dangerous fire season following heavy rains throughout winter and spring, leading to a large fuel load for summer.

It has also been seven and a half years after the devastation of Black Saturday, in which 173 people lost their lives, and efforts continue to reduce any chance of a repeat.

Risk landscape manager David Watson said: "Towns such as Daylesford, Hepburn Springs, Blackwood, Trentham, Castlemaine and the Gisborne-Woodend corridor are all at high risk.

"Importantly, the revised zones must ensure that our annual fuel management program is guided by a risk-based approach and that it contributes to an overall risk target of 70 per cent for Victoria.

"If the bushfire risk is at 70 per cent, bushfire fuels have been reduced by about one-third of the maximum risk.

"It's important people who live and work in these areas have the opportunity to share their experience and knowledge with us as we work to improve the effectiveness of our fire management strategies."

Residents have been encouraged to give feedback before November 25 in response to the proposed new fire management plan on the DELWP website at http://haveyoursay.delwp.vic.gov.au/westcentral-bushfire-risk-landscape.

urn:contentItem:4R8G-PWC0-TX4S-M18T-00000-00Court win sees Garrett face his first forest fire2007-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisAPg. 4Court win sees Garrett face his first forest fireThe Canberra Times

In his letter to Mr Garrett, Senator Brown pointed out the minister had the power, under clause 102 of the federal Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, to "insist that the intention of the Regional Forestry Agreement to protect rare and endangered species be upheld".

Senator Brown wrote, "Or else, you may nullify the RFA and bring forestry operations directly under the Act."

Mr Garrett's office did not return calls yesterday.

The two high-profile politicians and environmental activists were friends when Mr Garrett was president of the Australian Conservation Foundation and singer with Midnight Oil.

But when Mr Garrett, as opposition environment spokesman, declared his support for the controversial Tasmanian pulp mill last month, Senator Brown publicly declared their long friendship was over and accused Mr Garrett of abandoning his principles. The decision to allow logging to proceed in the Wielangta forest could be an embarrassment for the Australian government delegation at the United Nations climate change conference in Bali next week.

One of seven priority mitigation measures listed for discussion is curbing greenhouse emissions from clearing of forests.

"It sends a message of contempt and indifference to critical climate change issues by the government of Australia," Senator Brown said.

About 15,000 politicians, government officials and lobbyists are due to attend the Bali conference.

UN officials have warned the meeting is not expected to result in "big announcements on cuts" to emissions but say deforestation is one area where the meeting might break new ground.

Developing nations will seek to establish incentives and financial support from developed nations to stop cutting down their forests. Australia is the only developed nation among the world's top 20 land- clearing countries, a list that includes Cambodia, Burma, the Sudan, Bolivia and the Philippines.

urn:contentItem:46MM-6T80-015G-Y0CX-00000-00<published>2002-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:28:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Scientist warns of forest fire catastrophe</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Chris McCall</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">INDONESIA'S top expert on forest fires has said that the current blazes in Borneo and Sumatra could be the death knell for those islands' tropical forests and were likely to burn for months.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bambang Hero Saharjo said the fires appeared unlikely to go out until February, unless serious action were taken to put them out.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But he poured scorn on the Indonesian Government's feeble attempts to deal with the problem and said it had learned little from the annual fire disasters of the past five years.</p><p>"Three presidents have declared national disasters. Why was that not used as a warning?" asked Mr Saharjo, of Bogor Agricultural University, Indonesia's top institution for plant sciences.</p><p>He said a World Bank prediction that Sumatra's forests would vanish by 2005 now looked likely to be fulfilled and the same might be true of Kalimantan.</p><p>Mr Saharjo said this year's problems had not even yet been declared a disaster.</p><p>Instead of setting to and tackling the fires, the regional and central authorities were wasting time arguing about who was responsible for dealing with the problem.</p><p>This week, the latest images from the US NOAA satellite -- the region's main source of information about hotspots -- showed thick bands of red stretching right across West and Central Kalimantan.</p><p>The image showed 2929 hotspots in Kalimantan, Indonesia's part of Borneo. Nearly 90 per cent of them were in those two provinces.</p><p>More than 150 hotspots were also detected in Sumatra and its offshore islands.</p><p>Each hotspot represents an area of unusually high temperature -- usually indicating the presence of one or more fires within it.</p><p> Mr Saharjo said evidence was mixed so far about whether this disaster was caused by smallholders or by illegal burning of land by forestry companies. Both have been blamed for the problem in the past.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XR9-2NG1-JD34-V39W-00000-00Caution urged after fires2019-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 5Caution urged after firesEmma D'Agostino

POLICE and firefighters have appealed for information after two fires along Elmore-Barnadown Road, near Elmore and Goornong, yesterday.

Emergency services received reports of fire about 3.30pm.

CFA District 2 commander Chris Jacobsen said a fire on the roadside near the intersection with Ellis Road was dealt with by local crews.

It burnt a small area of the roadside grass and part of a paddock.

A second fire, further towards Elmore, consumed a hay shed and its contents and more than 70 hectares of paddock.

At its peak, there were 25 CFA units responding with support from Forest Fire Management Victoria crews, two firefighting helicopters and private units.

Mr Jacobsen thanked all those involved for their assistance.

Between ground crews and aerial support, firefighters saved the house and a shed and managed to pull the fire up before it crossed the Campaspe River.

Police were initially there managing traffic, but their role turned to making preliminary inquiries as the fire was made safe.

Both the fires are being treated as suspicious, and police and CFA are investigating.

Mr Jacobsen urged people to exercise caution given the dry conditions.

"CFA would ask people to limit any activity in the middle of the day that might cause fires," he said.

He suggested people make the most of the mornings, when the weather was cooler.

Yesterday's incidents had shown the fire danger, even on a day with temperatures in the mid-20s and "a slightly stronger than gentle breeze", Mr Jacobsen said.

Temperatures are set to soar next week, with temperatures of 38 and above forecast from Tuesday onward.

"We'd like people to be very careful out there because fires can kill and cause damage," Mr Jacobsen said.

Mr Jacobsen reminded people acts of negligence that resulted in fire could warrant criminal charges.

Police urged anyone with dash cam footage or information about any vehicles in the area about the time of fires to call the Bendigo Police Station on 5448 1300.

urn:contentItem:5XRF-TCF1-F0J6-J50V-00000-00Blazing trails2019-12-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Blazing trailsNicole Precel

Teagan Morris wields a chainsaw with a determined glare. The 22-year-old recently got her bulldozer ticket and has been fighting fires for four years.

There are concerns that catastrophic fire conditions in NSW could hit Victoria over summer, and Ms Morris is ready for it.

"[From] when I first started to now, it's changed a lot. My age and the fact I was female was quite unusual," she said.

The number of female firefighters remains low in Victoria - in the Metropolitan Fire Brigade only 81 of about 2000 firefighters are women, while 5000 Country Fire Authority volunteers are women, compared with 30,000 men.

But Ms Morris is among a growing number of women countering the "blokey" perception of firefighting.

Melbourne Water firefighters protect 156,000 hectares of water supply catchments and work alongside CFA and the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP).

During summer, the Melbourne Water fire crews are on watch 24/7, monitoring fires sparked by lightning. It's a big job. About 60 per cent of Melbourne's water storage capacity comes from Gippsland's Thomson Dam, which was threatened by fire last February.

Melbourne Water firefighting crew leader and operations officer Renelle Verkes was part of the battle to stop that blaze.

The 46-year-old joined the Hoddles Creek CFA at 14 and has fought the 2009 Black Saturday fires and countless others since.

"You could go to the football club or netball club, I went CFA," she said.

Back then, women made tea and sandwiches for the male firefighters, or did administration.

"It wasn't heard of - a female being a lieutenant or holding a position of authority in the brigade."

The mother of two worked her way through the ranks from a project firefighter and is an operations officer now.

"Don't think you can't do it, because you can," she said.

"I have worked very hard to get to where I am today. It's not something that's easy, it's something you have to work for. You have to work hard - that doesn't matter whether you're male or female."

Melbourne Water's team leader of water civil maintenance James Tite, who is based out of Healesville, has noticed "a big shift". This season there are 22 women and 82 men working in its fire crews.

"It's really good too, from a diversity point of view. It brings different skills and thinking," he said.

Ms Morris said advertising roles in a more inclusive manner (including images of women) helped with the push.

"The major thing they are doing is educating people that females can learn how to do these roles, and there is room for them as well. It's not just a male industry," she said.

That's a lesson MFB commander Donna Wheatley learnt about 16 years ago when she was working in administration at the fire brigade.

Someone told her she'd make a great firefighter.

"At that point I didn't even realise that there were any women who were firefighters," she said.

She's since spent 15 years with crews on trucks and became one of the first of two MFB women to graduate to the rank of commander last year.

"Although it's a cliche, you can't be what you can't see. And it's great to see more women considering firefighting as a career for them."

Chloe Collins, 33, a project firefighter with DELWP, just returned from a deployment fighting fires at Buchan, Buchan South and Ensay.

The Wantirna South woman swapped being a laboratory analyst and studying a bachelor of science to start a career in firefighting in November last year.

"It looks like we've been off to an early start too. We've had a few fires out in Gippsland already," she said.

"We've gone into rotation this early in the season."

Along with deployments, Ms Collins is also juggling motherhood.

"The challenge is definitely very real with three young kids," she said.

"They are very proud, actually - 'Mum's a firefighter' - so they are pretty stoked about that, they do like to boast a lot."

Beth Roberts, Forest Fire Management Victoria Gippsland deputy chief officer, is also raising a young family and pursuing a career that she is passionate about.

"It's a desire to keep showing my young girls that being a woman in a leadership roles is really empowering," she said.

The 41-year-old from Maffra said change was happening, but there was more to be done.

"I have seen women progress from traditional auxiliary roles into really high-level operational roles, whether that's as a sector commander on the field right through to my role as chief," Ms Roberts said.

In Forest Fire Management Victoria, about 20 per cent of frontline firefighting roles are women: 140 to 519 men.

At Myrtleford CFA station, with dwindling volunteer numbers, captain Gloria Pizzolitto says it's more important now than ever that people apply, regardless of gender.

"[We've] realised it's not just a man's domain any more," she said.

The 30-year-old became a volunteer 12 years ago after a push from her brother.

"I was quite happy to be part of the crew, looking out for the community in times of need," Ms Pizzolitto said.

urn:contentItem:5M08-JB51-JD34-V2WS-00000-00Rain causes slashing delays2016-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:28:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Rain causes slashing delaysSophie Boyd

SPRING's wet weather has delayed Forest Fire Management Victoria grass slashing fire preparedness program, and forced the closure of a number of firewood collection areas.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera District Manager Russell Manning said the grass slashing program was delayed due to heavy rain and access difficulties at sites.

He said crews were due to start the program shortly and after community consultation they would focus on public land around Stawell, Dimboola, Natimuk, Cavendish and Ararat.

Mr Manning said grass slashing was a vital part of fire prevention and heavy rain had encouraged grass growth in the region.

"With recent heavy rain across the district, however, there is high likelihood that many areas may need to be slashed again later in the year," he said.

"Slashing and mowing also promotes growth of native grasses, which helps to protect native vegetation stands along creeks and rivers."

Mr Manning said the wet weather had led to the closure of some fire collection areas due to safety concerns.

"Our staff have been vigilant in their assessment of conditions and have advised that many of areas are either inaccessible due to recent heavy rain or track conditions are such that providing access would only damage tracks," he said.

He said the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning would not open the following fire collection areas:

Mr Manning said all other areas are safe for collectors.

"We believe that there are adequate supplies of firewood in these areas, of varying sizes and quality," he said.

"Unless otherwise advised, all other designated Firewood Collection Areas will remain open until 30 November 2016."

Mr Manning asked residents to collect firewood by hand and said to be prepared to carry the wood some distance to their vehicle.

He said it was illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence.
